description: This course is the second semester of a two-semester sequence for first-year students admitted to the Collge's Integrated Studies Program. Topics will vary from year to year. For a current description, please see http://www.upenn.edu/curf/bfs/in-the-college.
name: INTEGRATED STUDIES II: THE ORDER OF THINGS

section.name: INTEGRATED STUDIES II: THE ORDER OF THINGS

values.comments:
This course served as an introduction to humanity's attempt, past and present, to understand the world and the human place in it. Students examined how people's understandings of the shape of the world are important to their own conceptions of human nature. The course consisted of four main parts. One each was in Political Science, Comparative Literature, and Physics, in which experts in their fields will guide a broad introduction to what their discipline can offer to the topic of the Order of Things. These three parts proceeded by large lectures and intimate discussions and had readings and assignments of their own. In a fourth part of the class, students explored their own attempts to make sense of these broader questions, using what they learned in their individual streams. Assignments consisted of a variety of readings, papers, problem sets, and projects, all designed to help students explore both the individual parts of the course and the ways in which they fit together. Readings included works by Aristotle, Milton, Locke, Bacon, Newton, Machiavelli, Nietzsche, Hegel, Marx, Darwin, and Einstein.

For the most part, students were less satisfied with this semester of the Integrated Studies Program (ISP) than their previous semester. Students felt that the program on the whole "is a great idea but poorly executed." Some enjoyed it, calling it an "excellent and valuable experience." Most class members, however, were frustrated by the lack of a "unifying theme to drive the course." Some program members found the political science stream disorganized, with "some of the readings about politics, while others seemed unrelated." Other students expressed discontent with the intense focus on only Milton's Paradise Lost in the literature stream. Students thought the physics stream was ineffective because too many complicated concepts were either crammed into a short period of time or "over-simplified.”

Students liked the organization of Professor Balasubramanian's lectures, but felt that his communication skills were lacking. Other students though that Professor Balasubramanian "taught the physics section class as well as it could be taught," though hard sciences in the ISP program are automatically less "stimulating and accessible."

This course was limited to students in the Integrated Studies residential program, part of the Benjamin Franklin Scholars program. Most of the students agreed that the workload was very heavy; class members described the work as "unduly difficult" and one claimed that it "consumed [his or her] first year." Another student was displeased by the frequency with which the course met.

section.name: INTEGRATED STUDIES II: THE ORDER OF THINGS

values.comments:
This course served as an introduction to humanity's attempt, past and present, to understand the world and the human place in it. Students examined how people's understandings of the shape of the world are important to their own conceptions of human nature. The course consisted of four main parts. One each was in Political Science, Comparative Literature, and Physics, in which experts in their fields will guide a broad introduction to what their discipline can offer to the topic of the Order of Things. These three parts proceeded by large lectures and intimate discussions and had readings and assignments of their own. In a fourth part of the class, students explored their own attempts to make sense of these broader questions, using what they learned in their individual streams. Assignments consisted of a variety of readings, papers, problem sets, and projects, all designed to help students explore both the individual parts of the course and the ways in which they fit together. Readings included works by Aristotle, Milton, Locke, Bacon, Newton, Machiavelli, Nietzsche, Hegel, Marx, Darwin, and Einstein.

For the most part, students were less satisfied with this semester of the Integrated Studies Program (ISP) than their previous semester. Students felt that the program on the whole "is a great idea but poorly executed." Some enjoyed it, calling it an "excellent and valuable experience." Most class members, however, were frustrated by the lack of a "unifying theme to drive the course." Some program members found the political science stream disorganized, with "some of the readings about politics, while others seemed unrelated." Other students expressed discontent with the intense focus on only Milton's Paradise Lost in the literature stream. Students thought the physics stream was ineffective because too many complicated concepts were either crammed into a short period of time or "over-simplified.”

Overall, students liked Professor Smith, who taught the political science stream. They declared that he was "very passionate about the material." Some students found Professor Smith "brilliant" and "hilarious" but at times "verbose." Most felt that his communication skills were excellent.

This course was limited to students in the Integrated Studies residential program, part of the Benjamin Franklin Scholars program. Most of the students agreed that the workload was very heavy; class members described the work as "unduly difficult" and one claimed that it "consumed [his or her] first year." Another student was displeased by the frequency with which the course met.

section.name: INTEGRATED STUDIES II: THE ORDER OF THINGS

values.comments:
The course serves as an introduction to our attempts, past and present, to understand the world and the human place in it.  It examines how peoples' understandings of the shape of the world are important to their own conceptions of human nature. These ways of understanding the larger cosmos might emerge from the idea that abstract laws guide all things and all human societies. They might posit that the internal characters of individual parts have their own shaping power on the structures of the whole. They might also rest on this or that hypothesis of transcendence as an ultimate source of the order of things, large and small.  The course consists of four main parts. One each is in Political Science, Comparative Literature, and Physics, in which experts in their fields guide a broad introduction to what their discipline can offer to the topic of The Order of Things. These three parts are constituent of large lectures and intimate discussion. They each have readings and assignments of their own. In a fourth part of the class, students will explore their own attempts to make sense of these broader questions, using what they have learned in the individual streams.
A significant amount of students found the course to be less enjoyable than it’s first-semester counterpart.  One student summed up the course as “an excellent and valuable experience,” but felt the work required “consumed [the student’s] first year.”  Professor Wilson’s Literature stream was dominated heavily by grammar and syntax.  Overall, students felt the course’s attempt to mesh three different disciplines was “a good idea, but poorly executed.”

Many students found Professor Wilson to be very knowledgeable about the material, but felt Professor Wilson had trouble communicating it effectively.  Students overwhelmingly found Professor Wilson’s lectures to be difficult to understand and take notes on due to the very fast pace of the lecturing.  Furthermore, many students craved significantly more guidance on what was expected of them on the assignments.  

Assignments consist of a variety of readings, papers, problem sets, and projects that are designed to help students explore both the individual parts of the course and the ways in which they fit together.  This course has no prerequisites. Together with Integrated Studies for Fall semester it fulfills 3 of the College's general requirements, sectors 4 and 7, plus one more of each student's choosing.

values.name: INTEGRATED STUDIES II: THE ORDER OF THINGS
